page.title: 13NATURE IN SANTON DOWNHAM (1)
page.content: Since the block is in the heart of Breckland, it has a climate unique to the British Isles. It has a low rainfall of 600mm per year, in particular only 160mm between April and September; Warmer summers and colder winters than elsewhere with frost recorded in every month of the year. These figures are for 1960_64 and were recorded at Santon Downham. The soil is generally sandy, with flints on top of chalk and varies considerably in thickness. Much of the sand arrived during great sandblows of the 17th century. The surrounding land then was sparse heathland with many rabbit warrens and enough sand was blown from Lakenheath Warren in 1668 to bury buildings and block the L. Ouse at Santon.
